leftBox.title: First to know. First to go.

about.title: About
about.metaDescription: The story behind Bridge Up - a real-time bridge status app for the St. Lawrence Seaway region.
about.heading: The bridge was up.

story.paragraph1: If you live near the Welland Canal, you know the frustration. You're running late, you hit the bridge, and the bridge is up. No idea how long you'll be waiting.
story.paragraph2: The official Seaway website exists, but it's clunky and not something you can safely check while driving. They've been promising a redesign for years. They eventually added Google and Waze integration, but in practice it's slow and unreliable. I wanted something I could actually glance at on CarPlay.
story.paragraph3: So I built Bridge Up. A simple app that tells you if the bridge is open before you get there, and even shows you the boat that's passing through.
story.paragraph4: Bridge Up is a work in progress. Got ideas or feedback? Reach out via
story.paragraph4End: . And if you find it useful, you can

support.heading: Want to support Bridge Up?
support.description: If you find Bridge Up useful and want to help cover the costs of keeping it running (Apple developer fees, server hosting, etc.), you can buy me a coffee

faq.heading: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.a1: Yes! Bridge Up is completely free with all features unlocked. No subscriptions, no in-app purchases, no paywalls. It's a passion project born from my own frustration of getting stuck at bridges. My costs are minimal, so I'd rather keep it free and useful for everyone.
faq.a2: Our predictions use 95% confidence intervals based on the 300 most recent closures for each bridge. Most predictions are accurate within a few minutes. Keep in mind it's only an estimate using past closure data as a guide, meaning it can be wildly wrong at times.
faq.q3: Where does the boat tracking data come from?
faq.a3: Boat tracking data comes from multiple sources. The primary source is a personal AIS antenna I operate in the St. Catharines region. Additional coverage is provided by AISHub, a community-run AIS database. This feature is new and the data sources are frequently changing. If you have an AIS setup in the Montreal region and would like to contribute data, please reach out!
faq.a4: Android is something I'll consider, but for now Bridge Up is available on web and iOS with full CarPlay support.
